# Sir Simon Russell Beale Sir Simon Russell Beale, CBE (born 12 January 1961) is a British actor. He has been described by [The Independent](/article/en/The_Independent) as "the greatest stage actor of his generation." He has received various accolades, including two [BAFTA](/article/en/BAFTA) Awards, three [Laurence Olivier Awards](/article/en/Laurence_Olivier_Award), and a [Tony Award](/article/en/Tony_Award). For his services to drama, he was knighted by [Queen Elizabeth II](/article/en/Elizabeth_II) in 2019. ## Early life and education Beale was born on 12 January 1961 in [Penang](/article/en/Penang), [Federation of Malaya](/article/en/Federation_of_Malaya) (present-day [Malaysia](/article/en/Malaysia)), one of six children of Captain, later Lieutenant General, Sir Peter Beale and his wife Julia née Winter. His father was serving in the [Army Medical Services](/article/en/Royal_Army_Medical_Corps) at the time of his birth. From 1991 to 1994, Beale's father served as Surgeon-General of HM Armed Forces. Both of his parents were doctors, and several other members of Beale's family have successfully pursued careers in medicine. Beale was first drawn to the performing arts when, at the age of eight, he became a chorister at [St Paul's Cathedral](/article/en/St_Paul's_Cathedral) and a pupil at the adjoining [St Paul's Cathedral School](/article/en/St_Paul's_Cathedral_School). His secondary education was undertaken at the independent [Clifton College](/article/en/Clifton_College) in [Bristol](/article/en/Bristol). His first stage performance was as Hippolyta in [A Midsummer Night's Dream](/article/en/A_Midsummer_Night's_Dream) at primary school. In the sixth form at Clifton, he also performed in [Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead](/article/en/Rosencrantz_and_Guildenstern_Are_Dead), a play in which he would later star at the National Theatre. According to the Russian Wikipedia version, at 14, he first appeared on stage in the role of Desdemona in a production by the "Redgrave" school theater at Clifton College. After Clifton, he attended [Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge](/article/en/Gonville_and_Caius_College,_Cambridge), and obtained a first in English, after which he was offered a place to undertake a PhD. He pursued further studies at [Guildhall School of Music and Drama](/article/en/Guildhall_School_of_Music_and_Drama), initially training as a singer but changing to acting after a short time, and graduating in 1983. ## Career ### Early work Beale first came to the attention of theatre-goers in the late 1980s with a series of lauded comic performances, which were on occasion extremely camp, in such plays as [The Man of Mode](/article/en/The_Man_of_Mode) by [George Etherege](/article/en/George_Etherege) and [Restoration](/article/en/Restoration_(play)) by [Edward Bond](/article/en/Edward_Bond) at the [Royal Shakespeare Company](/article/en/Royal_Shakespeare_Company) (RSC). He broadened his range in the early 1990s with moving performances as Konstantin in Chekhov's [The Seagull](/article/en/The_Seagull), as Oswald in Ibsen's [Ghosts](/article/en/Ghosts_(play)), Ferdinand in [The Duchess of Malfi](/article/en/The_Duchess_of_Malfi) and as Edgar in [King Lear](/article/en/King_Lear). At the first annual [Ian Charleson Awards](/article/en/Ian_Charleson_Awards) in January 1991, he received a special commendation for his 1990 performances of Konstantin in The Seagull, Thersites in [Troilus and Cressida](/article/en/Troilus_and_Cressida) and [Edward II](/article/en/Edward_II_(play)) in Edward II, all at the RSC. It was at the RSC that he first worked with [Sam Mendes](/article/en/Sam_Mendes), who directed him as Thersites in Troilus and Cressida, as [Richard III](/article/en/Richard_III_(play)) and as Ariel in [The Tempest](/article/en/The_Tempest), in the last of which he revealed a fine tenor voice. Mendes also directed him as Iago in [Othello](/article/en/Othello) at the [Royal National Theatre](/article/en/Royal_National_Theatre) and in Mendes's farewell productions at the [Donmar Warehouse](/article/en/Donmar_Warehouse) in 2002, Chekhov's [Uncle Vanya](/article/en/Uncle_Vanya), in which Beale played the title role, and [Twelfth Night](/article/en/Twelfth_Night), in which he played Malvolio. He won the 2003 Laurence Olivier Award for Uncle Vanya. Since 1995, he has been a regular at the National Theatre, where his roles have included Mosca in [Ben Jonson](/article/en/Ben_Jonson)'s [Volpone](/article/en/Volpone) opposite [Michael Gambon](/article/en/Michael_Gambon), George in [Tom Stoppard](/article/en/Tom_Stoppard)'s [Jumpers](/article/en/Jumpers) and the lead in [Humble Boy](/article/en/Humble_Boy) by [Charlotte Jones](/article/en/Charlotte_Jones_(playwright)), a part written specially for him. In 1997, he played the pivotal role of Kenneth Widmerpool in a television adaptation of [Anthony Powell](/article/en/Anthony_Powell)'s [A Dance to the Music of Time](/article/en/A_Dance_to_the_Music_of_Time), for which he won the Best Actor award at the [British Academy Television Awards](/article/en/British_Academy_Television_Awards) in 1998. The following year, he was a key part of [Trevor Nunn](/article/en/Trevor_Nunn)'s ensemble, playing in [Leonard Bernstein](/article/en/Leonard_Bernstein)'s [Candide](/article/en/Candide_(musical)) (Voltaire/Pangloss), [Edward Bulwer-Lytton](/article/en/Edward_Bulwer-Lytton)'s Money and [Maxim Gorky](/article/en/Maxim_Gorky)'s Summerfolk at the National. In autumn 2006, he played [Galileo](/article/en/Galileo_Galilei) in [David Hare](/article/en/David_Hare)'s adaption of [Brecht](/article/en/Bertolt_Brecht)'s [Life of Galileo](/article/en/Life_of_Galileo) and as Face in [The Alchemist](/article/en/The_Alchemist_(play)). ### 2000s In 2000, he played [Hamlet](/article/en/Hamlet) in a production directed by [John Caird](/article/en/John_Caird_(director)) for the National Theatre, a role for which he was described by [The Daily Telegraph](/article/en/The_Daily_Telegraph) as "portly [and] relatively long in the tooth". In 2005, Beale was directed by [Deborah Warner](/article/en/Deborah_Warner) as Cassius in [Julius Caesar](/article/en/Julius_Caesar_(play)) alongside [Ralph Fiennes](/article/en/Ralph_Fiennes) as Antony. That same year, he played the title role in [Macbeth](/article/en/Macbeth) at the [Almeida Theatre](/article/en/Almeida_Theatre). In 2007, he reprised his 2005 Broadway role as King Arthur in the [Monty Python](/article/en/Monty_Python) musical [Spamalot](/article/en/Spamalot) at the [Palace Theatre, London](/article/en/Palace_Theatre,_London). From December 2007 to March 2008, he played Benedick in [Much Ado About Nothing](/article/en/Much_Ado_About_Nothing) directed by [Nicholas Hytner](/article/en/Nicholas_Hytner) at the National Theatre and from February to July 2008, he played Andrew Undershaft in Hytner's production of Shaw's [Major Barbara](/article/en/Major_Barbara); he then appeared in [Harold Pinter](/article/en/Harold_Pinter)'s A Slight Ache and Landscape. In 2008, he made his debut as a television presenter, fronting the BBC series [Sacred Music](/article/en/Sacred_Music_(TV_series)) with [Harry Christophers](/article/en/Harry_Christophers) and [The Sixteen](/article/en/The_Sixteen). Various specials and a second series have since been produced; the most recent episode (Monteverdi in Mantua: The Genius of the Vespers) was broadcast in 2015. In spring 2009, Beale and Sam Mendes collaborated on The Winter's Tale and [The Cherry Orchard](/article/en/The_Cherry_Orchard), in which Beale played Leontes and Lopakhin respectively, at the [Brooklyn Academy of Music](/article/en/Brooklyn_Academy_of_Music), later transferring to the [Old Vic Theatre](/article/en/Old_Vic). From 2009 to 2010, he played [George Smiley](/article/en/George_Smiley) in the BBC Radio 4 adaptation of all the [John le Carré](/article/en/John_le_Carré) novels in which Smiley featured. These were broadcast in nineteen 90-minute or 60-minute full cast radio plays. From March to June 2010, he played Sir Harcourt Courtly in [London Assurance](/article/en/London_Assurance), again at the National. In August 2010, he appeared in the first West End revival of [Deathtrap](/article/en/Deathtrap_(play)) by [Ira Levin](/article/en/Ira_Levin). In March 2011, he made his debut with [The Royal Ballet](/article/en/The_Royal_Ballet) in [Alice's Adventures in Wonderland](/article/en/Alice's_Adventures_in_Wonderland_(ballet)) as the Duchess. In October 2011, he returned to the National to star as [Joseph Stalin](/article/en/Joseph_Stalin) in the premiere of [Collaborators](/article/en/Collaborators_(play)) by [John Hodge](/article/en/John_Hodge_(screenwriter)), for which he won Best Actor at the 2012 [Evening Standard Awards](/article/en/Evening_Standard_Theatre_Awards). According to the Russian Wikipedia, this production received the Laurence Olivier Award. ### 2010s In 2010–11, Beale played the Coalition Home Secretary William Towers in the two final series of BBC One's spy drama, [Spooks](/article/en/Spooks_(TV_series)). He played the title role in [Timon of Athens](/article/en/Timon_of_Athens) at the National Theatre from July to October 2012. The production was broadcast to cinemas around the world (as was Collaborators earlier) on 1 November 2012 through the [National Theatre Live](/article/en/National_Theatre_Live) programme. He starred in a revival of [Peter Nichols](/article/en/Peter_Nichols)' [Privates on Parade](/article/en/Privates_on_Parade) as part of [Michael Grandage](/article/en/Michael_Grandage)'s new West End season at the [Noël Coward Theatre](/article/en/Noël_Coward_Theatre) from December 2012 to March 2013. In 2013, he won the British Academy Television Award (BAFTA) for Best Supporting Actor for his performance as [Falstaff](/article/en/Falstaff) in the BBC's [The Hollow Crown](/article/en/The_Hollow_Crown) series of TV films about Shakespeare's historical dramas [Richard II](/article/en/Richard_II_(play)); [Henry IV, Part 1](/article/en/Henry_IV,_Part_1); [Henry IV, Part 2](/article/en/Henry_IV,_Part_2); and [Henry V](/article/en/Henry_V_(play)). That same year he appeared in National Theatre Live: 50 Years On Stage (2013). Beale appeared alongside [John Simm](/article/en/John_Simm) in Harold Pinter's [The Hothouse](/article/en/The_Hothouse) at the Trafalgar Studios from May to August 2013, directed by [Jamie Lloyd](/article/en/Jamie_Lloyd). From January 2014, he played the title role in King Lear at the National Theatre, directed once again by Sam Mendes. Also from 2014 to 2016, he starred as a main cast member in Showtime's [Penny Dreadful](/article/en/Penny_Dreadful_(TV_series)), in which he played Ferdinand Lyle, a homosexual epigraphist from the British Museum. In 2014, Beale was appointed the Cameron Mackintosh Professor of Contemporary Theatre at [Oxford University](/article/en/University_of_Oxford), based at [St Catherine's College](/article/en/St_Catherine's_College,_Oxford). From May to July 2015, he starred in Temple, a new play at the Donmar Warehouse about the 2011 [United Kingdom anti-austerity protests](/article/en/2011_United_Kingdom_anti-austerity_protests). In September and October 2015, he played [Samuel Foote](/article/en/Samuel_Foote) in Mr Foote's Other Leg at the [Hampstead Theatre](/article/en/Hampstead_Theatre). It transferred to the [Theatre Royal Haymarket](/article/en/Theatre_Royal_Haymarket) from October 2015 to January 2016. In November 2016, Beale returned to the Royal Shakespeare Company in [Stratford-upon-Avon](/article/en/Stratford-upon-Avon), to play Prospero in The Tempest. In June 2017, it transferred to the [Barbican Centre](/article/en/Barbican_Centre) in London. In July 2018, Beale returned to the National, starring opposite [Ben Miles](/article/en/Ben_Miles) and [Adam Godley](/article/en/Adam_Godley) in [The Lehman Trilogy](/article/en/The_Lehman_Trilogy), again directed by Mendes. It transferred to the [Piccadilly Theatre](/article/en/Piccadilly_Theatre) in the West End in May 2019. Beale starred in the title role of Richard II at the Almeida Theatre from December 2018 to February 2019. ### 2020s During the [COVID-19 pandemic](/article/en/COVID-19_pandemic), Beale contributed as a guest speaker to The Show Must Go Online's performance of Timon of Athens. In the summer of 2021, Beale played [JS Bach](/article/en/Johann_Sebastian_Bach) in the world première of Nina Raine's Bach and Sons, directed by frequent collaborator Nicholas Hytner at his company's [Bridge Theatre](/article/en/Bridge_Theatre) in London. During this time he re-rehearsed for the post-COVID return in late September of the Broadway transfer of the National Theatre production of The Lehman Trilogy whose run had been halted on 12 March 2020 by the pandemic. Beale reprised his role (along with Adam Godley) but, due to stage commitments in London for the RSC in the third part of the [Wolf Hall](/article/en/Wolf_Hall) trilogy, Ben Miles was replaced by [Adrian Lester](/article/en/Adrian_Lester). Beale won a Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play for his performance in The Lehman Trilogy. In April 2023, it was announced that Beale had been cast as Ser Simon Strong in the second season of [House of the Dragon](/article/en/House_of_the_Dragon). The series is a prequel to [Game of Thrones](/article/en/Game_of_Thrones), and his character is the governor of [Harrenhal](/article/en/Harrenhal). In April 2025, Beale is scheduled to return to the Royal Shakespeare Company to play the title role in [Titus Andronicus](/article/en/Titus_Andronicus) in the [Swan Theatre](/article/en/Swan_Theatre_(Stratford)), Stratford-upon-Avon, directed by Max Webster. ## Personal life Beale is a past president of the [Anthony Powell Society](/article/en/Anthony_Powell_Society), a tribute to his portrayal of Kenneth Widmerpool. Beale is gay and has publicly come out. In the [Independent on Sunday](/article/en/The_Independent_on_Sunday) 2006 Pink List – a list of the most influential gay men and women in the UK – he was placed at number 30. According to the German Wikipedia version, he lives with his partner in London. He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II, at [Buckingham Palace](/article/en/Buckingham_Palace), on 9 October 2019. ## Acting credits ### Film * [Orlando](/article/en/Orlando_(film)) (1992) - Earl of Moray * [Persuasion](/article/en/Persuasion_(1995_film)) (1995) - scheduled for 2025 ## Patronage Beale is a patron of the following organizations: * English Touring Theatre * South London Theatre * London Symphony Chorus * For Short Theatre Company * Diamond Fund for Choristers ## Awards and honors ### Honorary distinctions * Appointed a CBE in the 2003 Birthday Honours * Knight Bachelor in the 2019 Birthday Honours for services to drama * Honorary DLitt (Warwick) in 2005 * Honorary Bencher of Middle Temple in 2010 * Honorary DUniv (Open University) in 2010 * Honorary Freedom of the City of London for services to drama in 2011 * Cameron Mackintosh Visiting Professor of Contemporary Theatre, St. Catherine's College, Oxford in 2015 * Premio Shakespeare Award in 2018 * Honorary Fellow of Somerville College, Oxford in 2024 ### British Academy Television Awards * 1998 - Critics' Circle Theatre Award/John and Wendy Trewin Award for Timon of Athens * 2012 - Evening Standard Award for Best Actor for Collaborators ## Voice acting In the Italian versions of the works in which he acted, Simon Russell Beale was dubbed by various voice actors, including Vladimiro Conti, Marco Mete, Roberto Stocchi, Mino Caprio, Giorgio Lopez, Ambrogio Colombo, Gaetano Lizzio, Roberto Certomà, Gianni Giuliano, Emidio La Vella, Riccardo Peroni, Toni Orlandi, Stefano De Sando, Luca Biagini, and Bruno Alessandro. ## See also * [List of British actors](/article/en/List_of_British_actors) ## References ## Further reading * Trowbridge, Simon, The Company: A Biographical Dictionary of the Royal Shakespeare Company, Oxford: Editions Albert Creed, 2010.
